required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Long-term Effect of Low Frequency Stimulation on Aspiration and Freezing of Gait in PD With STN DBS
clinical_study.official_title: Long-term Effect of Low Frequency 60Hz Stimulation on Aspiration, Freezing of Gait and Other Axial and Motor Symptoms in PD Patients With Bilateral STN DBS

collaborator.agency: Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research

brief_summary.textblock: Our recent study (Xie et al, Neurology 2015; 84: 415-420) found that 60Hz stimulation, compared to the traditional 130Hz, decreased the aspiration frequency and swallowing difficulty, medication refractory freezing of gait (FOG), and other axial symptoms and parkinsonism in Parkinson patients with bilateral STN DBS. The benefit of 60Hz stimulation persisted during the 6-week study period, with worsening tremor in one patient. However, it remains unknown whether the benefit of 60Hz would persist on prolonged stimulation period, and whether there is carry-over effect across different conditions. Clarifying these questions is essential for the application of 60Hz stimulation chronically and confidently to treat medication refractory axial symptoms. Hence, the investigators would test the hypothesis that the 60Hz stimulation, compared to 130Hz, would have persistent benefit over an extended period (on average > 8-month study period) in reducing the swallowing dysfunction, FOG, and other axial symptoms in PD patients with bilateral STN DBS and medication refractory FOG at 130Hz stimulation, even after correcting the potential carry-over effects between stimulation conditions.

detailed_description.textblock:
The investigators will enroll 14 Parkinson patients with bilateral STN DBS and medication refractory FOG at 130Hz for two visits of at least 6-month apart. The 6 patients remaining on 60Hz stimulation after our previous study consisting of 7 patients will be assessed again once as visit-2 at least 15-month after previous visit-1 of their last study. It will have 20 patents complete for vist-1 and at least 18 patients complete for visit-2 in this randomized double-blind prospective crossover study with their usual medication "on" state, with 6-7 patients on each starting condition (60Hz vs 130Hz vs DBS off). Swallowing function on modified barium swallowing test and swallowing difficulty on questionnaire, FOG in stand-walk-sit test and questionnaire, and other axial and motor function will be assessed under each DBS condition. Changes in measurements between 60Hz and 130Hz at each visit and under 60Hz between two visits will be analyzed, with swallowing function and FOG as primary, and the rest as secondary outcomes, correcting for potential carryover effect. Changes between other DBS conditions might also be explored in this 2-year study.
This would be the first study on the long-term effect of 60Hz stimulation on dysphagia, FOG and other axial and motor symptoms in Parkinson patients with bilateral STN DBS and medication refractory FOG at 130Hz stimulation, which will have significant impact on the treatment of difficult axial symptoms of high morbidity and mortality.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Long-term effect of 60Hz compared to 130Hz on swallowing function (objective modified barium swallowing & swallowing questionnaire) & effect on freezing of gait (objective stand-walk-sit study & questionnaire) in PD patients with bilateral STN DBS
primary_outcome.time_frame: At least 6-month (on average 8-month) duration will be followed after the patient is on 60Hz stimulation

secondary_outcome.measure: Long-term effect of 60Hz compared to 130Hz stimulation on the overall parkinsonian motor symptoms (UPDRS-III score) in PD patients with bilateral STN DBS
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At least 6-month (on average 8-month) duration will be followed after the patient is on 60Hz stimulation

secondary_outcome.measure: Long-term effect of 60Hz compared to 130Hz stimulation on the overall axial symptoms (UPDRS-III axial subscore) in PD patients with bilateral STN DBS
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At least 6-month (on average 8-month) duration will be followed after the patient is on 60Hz stimulation

secondary_outcome.measure: Long-term effect of 60Hz compared to 130Hz stimulation on the overall tremor symptoms (UPDRS-III tremor subscore) in PD patients with bilateral STN DBS
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At least 6-month (on average 8-month) duration will be followed after the patient is on 60Hz stimulation

arm_group.description: Patients will have a randomized double-blind prospective crossover study with usual medication "on" state under 3 different DBS stimulation frequency condition (60Hz vs 130Hz vs DBS off). Aspiration frequency on modified barium swallowing test and swallowing difficulty on questionnaire, FOG in stand-walk-sit test and questionnaire, and other axial and motor function will be assessed under each DBS condition. Changes in measurements between 60Hz and 130Hz at each visit and under 60Hz between two visits of 8 months apart on average will be analyzed, with swallowing function and FOG as primary, and the rest as secondary outcomes, correcting for potential carryover effect. Changes between other DBS conditions might also be explored in this 2-year study.

intervention.description: Patients will have a randomized double-blind prospective crossover study with usual medication "on" state under 3 different DBS stimulation frequency condition (60Hz vs 130Hz vs DBS off). Aspiration frequency on modified barium swallowing test and swallowing difficulty on questionnaire, FOG in stand-walk-sit test and questionnaire, and other axial and motor function will be assessed under each DBS condition. Changes in measurements between 60Hz and 130Hz at each visit and under 60Hz between two visits of 8 months apart on average will be analyzed, with swallowing function and FOG as primary, and the rest as secondary outcomes, correcting for potential carryover effect. Changes between other DBS conditions might also be explored in this 2-year study.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- PD patients with bilateral STN DBS placement and FOG at 130Hz even at usual medication "on" state.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Known history of recent aspiration pneumonia

overall_official.affiliation: Department of Neurology, University of Chicago

facility.name: University of Chicago, Department of Neurology

results_reference.citation: Xie T, Vigil J, MacCracken E, Gasparaitis A, Young J, Kang W, Bernard J, Warnke P, Kang UJ. Low-frequency stimulation of STN-DBS reduces aspiration and freezing of gait in patients with PD. Neurology. 2015 Jan 27;84(4):415-20. doi: 10.1212/WNL.0000000000001184. Epub 2014 Dec 24.
